title: How to Prewash Fabric

steps.headline: Check the fabric type.
steps.description: Some fabrics can be prewashed at home using a regular washer and dryer. These include cotton, nylon, polyester, acrylic, and micro-fiber. Others should be taken to a dry cleaner for prewashing, including wool, silk, rayon, and acetate.

steps.headline: Separate your fabrics by color.
steps.description: Lights and darks should be washed separately. If you have several colors, it’s best to divide them and do a load for each. Sort these before you begin.

steps.headline: Color test your fabric.
steps.description: This is helpful if you want to see if your fabrics will bleed or run when washed. Take a piece of the fabric you want to test and let it sit for 30 minutes in a bowl of cool soapy water. If the water is colored after 30 minutes then the fabric will need to be washed by itself or not used. You can also use a fabric color fixative to keep colors from running. Follow package instructions for use.

steps.headline: Place cut pieces in a bag before washing.
steps.description: If you have strips or other cut pieces, you should place them into a lingerie bag before washing. This will help keep them from unraveling in the washer. You can also serge or zig zag stitch any cut pieces before washing, but this can be time consuming.

steps.headline: Set your washer to a cool, gentle cycle.
steps.description: Set your machine’s temperature to “cool” or "cold" and use the delicate cycle. If your washer has a “hand wash” setting, this is even better.

steps.headline: Add one-fourth the normal amount of a mild soap.
steps.description: You can use mild laundry detergent, or a special quilt soap like Quiltwash or Orvus. Don’t use much detergent, however. One-fourth the amount you would normally use will be sufficient.

steps.headline: Do not use fabric softener.
steps.description: Prewashing fabric prepares it for your projects. Fabric softeners, however, will change the texture of the cloth, making it harder to work with when you begin sewing.

steps.headline: Shake the fabric when the load is done.
steps.description: Once the washer is done, immediately take the fabric out. While it’s still damp, vigorously shake the fabric flat to remove wrinkles. This will be prevent creasing as the fabric dries.

steps.headline: Tumble dry the fabric.
steps.description: Place the damp fabric in the dryer. Use low heat and a gentle or delicate cycle, if available.

steps.headline: Remove the fabric from the dryer.
steps.description: Do this just after the dryer cycle ends. Lay the fabric flat and let it cool. If you leave the fabric wrinkled in the dryer after the cycle is over, it will form creases. You can also take the fabric out before the dryer cycle ends and let it hang dry to finish, if you prefer.

steps.headline: Take the fabric out just before the cycle is done, alternatively.
steps.description: This is another way to ensure that the fabric does not wrinkle or form creases. Take the fabric out of the dryer while it is still slightly damp. Then use an iron to press the fabric and finish drying it. Don't bother ironing the fabric if you're not going to use it right away, however, since storing it will cause creases.

Lingerie bag (if you have small cut pieces)
